node.title: Indoor air quality is a 'regulatory no-man's-land'. And that matters with COVID
node.alt: Mould growth in an air conditioning system
node.description: There's lots ofÂ talk about fixing ventilation to stop COVID, but bad indoor air has been a problem for decades. How will this change, and what can we do in the meantime?
node.content:
["Jeremy Stamkos was just 17 when he began decontaminating\u00a0hospital air-conditioning systems that were riddled with deadly fungal moulds.", "\"Unfortunately, we often got the call after people had died,\" says Mr Stamkos, now an indoor air consultant.", "", "
Jeremy Stamkos left school at 17 to work full-time in the family\u00a0business. He's seen his fair share of mouldy air conditioners.(Supplied: Jeremy Stamkos)
", "One incident he can't forget is the death of a young child in an oncology ward who had inhaled the mould Aspergillus fumigatus, which had been\u00a0growing in a neglected\u00a0air conditioning unit.", "\"The mould gets into the blood, up into the brain, takes over the lungs \u2014\u00a0it's horrific.\"", "The tragedy hit a nerve for Mr Stamkos.", "\u201cI had three young children at that stage myself, and one of my children was exactly the age of that child that passed away.\u201d", "These days Mr Stamkos works closely\u00a0with the Australian Institute of Refrigeration, Air conditioning and Heating (AIRAH) to advocate for clean indoor air.", "\u201cThe whole matter of indoor air quality is really coming to the forefront,\" Mr Stamkos says.", "\u201cNobody knows what is acceptable indoor air quality.\"", "
Is indoor air quality regulated?
", "The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the fact\u00a0there are still major ventilation problems in hospitals.", "And despite experiences with the airborne spread of coronavirus in quarantine hotels\u00a0\u2014\u00a0and\u00a0some attention being given to schools recently \u2014\u00a0indoor air quality is still largely unregulated.", "", "
Hospitals\u00a0and schools\u00a0have been in the\u00a0spotlight when it comes to indoor air quality.(ABC Melbourne: Kristian Silva)
", "The health problems associated with poor indoor air has been\u00a0estimated to cost\u00a0Australia $12 billion a year.", "Beyond moulds and viruses, indoor air pollutants include things like toxic chemicals given out by furnishings and building materials, and CO2 breathed out by humans.", "As well as being a sign of bad ventilation, high CO2 levels can also give people headaches, affect concentration, cognitive abilities and productivity.", "", "
Some quarantine hotels saw spread of SARS-CoV-2 before there was better understanding of airborne transmission of the virus.(AAP: James Ross)
", "
Outdoor air quality is monitored, so why not indoor?
", "", "
Blueprint: Breathing easy amid COVID-19
", "Queensland University of Technology indoor air quality expert Lidia Morawska\u00a0describes indoor air quality as a \"regulatory no-man's-land\".", "\"Ultimately it's the responsibility of venues to improve ventilation, but since there are no regulations \u2026 no-one feels obliged to do anything.\"", "She argues governments need to be monitoring indoor air and enforcing standards to reduce the health cost of poor indoor air quality, something that already occurs with outdoor air quality.", "The problem is there are no nationally agreed standards for indoor air quality.", "", "
A recent UK government campaign, called \"stop COVID-19 from hanging around\", urges people to\u00a0open windows more often.(UK Department of Health and Social Care)
", "Mr Stamkos has\u00a0been working to develop national standards for indoor air quality since 2017.", "\"People need to know what the benchmark is for indoor air quality,\" he says.", "He is hopeful that by 2024, there will be an enforceable standard.", "\"Then if there is a complaint, a health official could come in there and do the test and say if it is non-compliant with the standard. At the moment there's no such thing.\"", "The complexity of\u00a0the issue\u00a0means a number of portfolios involved at the federal, state and local government levels need to be involved.", "Less than 20 countries \u2014 several European and Asian countries \u2014 have national indoor air quality standards and most are not enforceable, Professor Morawska says.", "
We 'need to spend money to improve buildings'
", "", "
Experts say governments need to improve indoor air to prevent COVID-19
", "One of the challenges to improving air quality is the\u00a0trade-off between ventilation and\u00a0saving energy, Mr Stamkos says.", "\"When you bring in outside air to dilute the pollutants \u2014\u00a0CO2 and other things \u2014\u00a0it costs a lot of money to heat or cool that air.\"", "So the desire to save on energy costs has often compromised indoor air quality, especially in tightly sealed buildings.", "Shifting to better indoor air will\u00a0involve making changes to a lot of existing buildings.", "\"There's a huge amount of retrofitting to be done,\" Mr Stamkos says.", "\"Every litre of fresh air costs about 35 watts to heat or cool and it's just a lot of energy,\" says Robert Lord from Seed Engineering, who specialises in sustainable building services.", "\"There is a whole range of buildings out there that have really unhealthy ventilation characteristics.\"", "", "
Mould growing on a ventilation fan in a hospital.(Supplied: Jeremy Stamkos)
", "Architect Geoff Hanmer of OzSAGE, an expert group campaigning for better ventilation standards,\u00a0likens it to the changes that happened when cities had to stop the spread of cholera in the past.", "So what do we all do in the meantime?", "
Buildings 'should display indoor\u00a0air quality readings'
", "Mr Hamer says public venues that are doing the right thing when it comes to ventilation should display the fact.", "", "
A large-scale CO2 level display in a European theatre.(Getty Images: James Arthur Gekiere/Contributor)
", "\"If I ran a restaurant, I'd buy one of these big digit CO2 monitors and stick it on the wall so people could see it, because then they'd know I was taking it seriously and they could also see the level was OK,\" Mr Hamer says.", "\"When you go into a movie theatre in Japan, the CO2 reading in the theatre is projected onto the screen.\"", "Mr Lord agrees people have the right to know about the quality of air in public spaces, especially when they're paying to use them.", "\"I think if you're renting a hall\u00a0or a ballroom for a choir, taekwondo practice, or for your daughter's 21st, you should be able to see a sensor to know the amount of fresh air is being controlled and monitored.\"", "Meanwhile, experts agree the public can \"empower\" themselves by using low-cost electronic CO2 monitors to avoid poorly ventilated buildings.", "", "
Professor Morawska holding a small CO2 monitor that can be used to check ventilation levels.(ABC News: Emma Pollard)
", "Mr Stamkos imagines businesses and residents will start using them to push for change.", "\"I think there's going to be a huge demand that building owners provide acceptable indoor air quality.\"", "
Technology 'needs to be used intelligently'
", "People are also increasingly using portable air cleaners, but while HEPA filters can be useful, Mr Stamkos warns they can become a \"petri dish\" of mould if\u00a0not maintained properly.", "Other experts\u00a0suggest avoiding devices using unproven technology.", "When it comes to saving on the energy costs of ventilation, some buildings use\u00a0a system called \"demand control ventilation\", which\u00a0automatically adjusts the amount of outdoor air brought in according to how much CO2 is building up.", "This means that places that have crowds coming and going \u2014\u00a0think cinemas \u2014\u00a0can save on ventilation costs when the place is empty.", "", "
Jeremy Stamkos has made it his mission to advocate for clean indoor air.(Supplied: Jeremy Stamkos)
", "Mr Stamkos says this technology is useful but needs to be used intelligently.", "If, for example, it's really humid outside and you bring in a lot of air, this could overload the air conditioner and cause mould to build up \u2014\u00a0and this can have consequences he\u00a0is all too aware of.", "Other interventions, like upgrading air filters or changing the direction of air flow so people are less likely to breathe in airborne contaminants, are also important.", "Whatever the technology and whatever the costs, Professor Morwaska insists it will be worth it in the end.", "\"The whole society is paying for the health problems caused by poor indoor air,\" she says."]
